e1df1fdb-e6ed-4cd2-95dd-9219669654d6.description: Collaboration in the 21st century includes the capacity to work productively with different individuals and groups toward a common goal. Effective collaborators exhibit four core sub-competencies: strengthen relationships by incorporating diverse perspectives, using active listening skills, and focusing on solutions rather than problems.
e1df1fdb-e6ed-4cd2-95dd-9219669654d6.name: Collaboration

badge_template_activities.title: Select Bridge to Employment (BTE) youth participated in the 3-day Alliance Building & Training Session (ABTS), which is an annual international conference uniting global BTE programs. Youth collaborated with peers of various cultures and backgrounds to design, innovate, and produce a new generation prototype after learning about the intricacies of product development.

Collaborate with Johnson & Johnson professionals working in product development areas; conduct informational interviews to learn more about the seven key product development areas including finance, engineering, sales, marketing, public relations, claims, and product development.

In collaboration with product development team, develop a new generation prototype based on a current Johnson & Johnson product. Teams create their own Power Point presentations including background of product, situation analysis, recommendations, and project plan that encompasses the seven essential product development areas. Each team had the autonomy to bring their new generation prototype to life by creating a real life prototype, producing a commercial, or creating marketing materials.

2eae7bba-95ef-4fa3-a869-6059e70efdce.description: Intercultural Fluency is a set of skills and attitudes that allows an individual to navigate cultural divides. An inter-culturally fluent person has the ability to work, socialize, and connect with people who have different values than themselves.
2eae7bba-95ef-4fa3-a869-6059e70efdce.name: Intercultural Fluency

badge_template_activities.title: Collaborated with youth of various cultures and backgrounds to develop an increased awareness of cultural norms, values, and competencies.

Completed an interview assessment with FHI 360 staff. Criteria assessed included naming and describing the 4 sub-competencies of intercultural fluency; explaining the concept of the cultural iceberg; providing examples of community cultural norms explained by the iceberg; self-reflection of personal values; successful communication of cultural awareness and communication in two case studies.

7167a38b-6666-449f-887a-8ab1469774e6.description: Leadership in the 21st century is a process of social influence that empowers others towards the achievement of a common goal. Effective leaders exhibit four core sub-competencies: strengthen relationships by incorporating diverse perspectives, using active empathetic listening skills, influencing through innovation, and focusing on solutions rather than problems.
7167a38b-6666-449f-887a-8ab1469774e6.name: Leadership Excellence

badge_template_activities.title: Selected member of Bridge to Employment's Youth Leadership Council. Successful completion of a one-year term of service with active monthly participation in council meetings and initiatives.

f52ba5d7-2c9a-4fe4-bd5e-9b880b09434d.description: The STEM design process is a series of steps that serve as a foundation for finding a solution to a problem. These steps include: defining the problem, collecting data, brainstorming, developing, presenting, and improving solutions. This process gives youth the tools they need to solve real-world problems, enabling them to become locally aware, globally engaged citizens. Participants learn fundamentals of the design process, as well as training in 3D modeling and prototype development.
f52ba5d7-2c9a-4fe4-bd5e-9b880b09434d.name: STEM Design Process

badge_template_activities.title: Select Bridge to Employment (BTE) youth participated in the 6-day Alliance Building & Training Session (ABTS), which is an annual international conference uniting global BTE programs. After learning about the STEM design process, youth collaborated with peers of various cultures and backgrounds to design, build, test, and present a prototype of a mini-golf course that incorporated the construction of various simple machines into the design.

Create a workable solution to a real world problem by demonstrating an increase in knowledge of a variety of STEM concepts. As youth work through the STEM Design Process to create a solution, they will incorporate an understanding of convergent and divergent thinking, brainstorming strategies, simple machines, 3D modeling, construction, and prototyping into their design.

Teams create their own Power Point presentations describing the steps of the STEM Design Process and how each step contributed to the development of their solution. Each team member will present their own 3D model and working prototype to demonstrate the STEM concepts applied over the course of the 6-day event. Presentations will showcase the development of the solution from start to finish and will highlight both successes and failures encountered along the way.

9c9e0952-5178-4787-a263-381d4064fdf0.description: Virtual communication in the 21st century is when people communicate using one or more electronic devices or virtual platforms. An effective virtual communicator not only speaks with clarity and precision, uses stories to communicate ideas and increase engagement, but are also aware of their audience and are active listeners who can "hear" what is said verbally, what is not said, and can interpret body language effectively. They are also knowledgeable and proficient with multiple virtual tools.
9c9e0952-5178-4787-a263-381d4064fdf0.name: Virtual Communication

badge_template_activities.title: Virtual Engagement: Earners of the virtual communication badge engaged in professional trainings of virtual communication platforms and interactive tools including Blackboard Collaborate, Zoom, and Adobe Premier Rush.

Active Listening: Earners will engage in active listening exercises and demonstrate competency in paraphrasing, asking questions, expressing empathy, using engaged body language, avoiding judgment, as well as avoiding giving advice.

Lunch & Learn: Earners will prepare and deliver a three-minute presentation. The goal of the presentation is to use storytelling to engage the audience and provide a human side to an abstract topic. Successful presentations will include the use of effective hooks, clear introductions of conflict being resolved, providing clear meaning, and adhering to time constraints.

Respectful Listening thru I-Messages: Earners will engage in an interactive activity that requires them to respectfully and actively listen. Participants will engage in conversation and observe body language and non-verbal cues to assess respectful listening all while using I-Messages. Participants will identify how being sensitive to signals improves listening.

Digital Interviews: Earners will use their knowledge of Zoom to create meeting invites and schedule digital interviews with program partners. Earners will conduct recorded interviews centered on program recruitment, ensuring the creation and implementation of effective interview questions and appropriate probing.

Video Production: Using the virtual tools and communication content knowledge learned through this badge series, earners will conduct virtual interviews that will be recorded. Earners will then use their interview recordings to design and produce a recruitment video. These recruitment videos will be presented and showcased for final evaluation.

a743f0ec-e0cc-42da-a31f-e1accc1c5467.description: Working with Youth is a four-hour orientation and training session for Johnson & Johnson local operating company employees (BTE Volunteers) who are new to the BTE program and working with youth. Key concepts include: positive youth development, effective communication, active listening, and relationship-building practices.
a743f0ec-e0cc-42da-a31f-e1accc1c5467.name: Working with Youth

badge_template_activities.title: Reflection and Pair-Share Activity: Fact or Fiction? Myth or Truth?:  Through this self-reflection and pair-share activity, participants identify and dispel myths or preconceived notions about adolescents and their actions.
When I Was 15: In this assessment, participants identify the principles of positive youth development and how the "3Ps" (people, places, and purpose) are essential to building youth competencies.

Success Letter: Participants write a letter to an individual that supported the development of their knowledge, skills and abilities, articulating how the individual exhibited the five elements of the Developmental Relationship Framework.
Tell Your Story: Participants role play an introductory meeting with BTE youth.
What Did You Say?: During this Learning Activity, participants will practice different communication and active listening techniques.

Scenario Discussion: Participants read a scenario about a J&J  Volunteer and BTE Student and correctly identify the positive youth development practices that were utilized, as well as make recommendations for how the developmental framework could be used to build a more effective relationship.

a724eea2-7d8a-44f8-83e0-dc05fcb16947.description: Communication in the 21st century includes both verbal and nonverbal communication. An effective communicator can speak with clarity and precision in both formal and informal contexts. Effective communicators can use stories to communicate ideas and increase engagement; they are aware of their audience and use the appropriate tone and word choice. They are also active listeners who can "hear" what is said verbally, what is not said, and can interpret body language effectively.
a724eea2-7d8a-44f8-83e0-dc05fcb16947.name: Communication

badge_template_activities.title: Elevator Pitch: Earners will develop a 1-minute elevator pitch. A successful pitch will include a hook, a call to action, and a reason to be remembered. Earners will be assessed on pitch components, as well as their ability to speak with clarity, precision, and confidence.

Active Listening: Earners will engage in active listening exercises and demonstrate competency in paraphrasing, asking questions, expressing empathy, using engaged body language, avoiding judgment, as well as avoiding giving advice.

Respectful Listening Do's & Don'ts: Earners will engage in an interactive activity that requires them to respectfully and actively listen. Participants will engage in conversation and observe body language and non-verbal cues to assess respectful listening. Participants will identify how being sensitive to signals improves listening.

Lunch & Learn: Earners will prepare and deliver a three-minute presentation. The goal of the presentation is to use storytelling to engage the audience and provide a human side to an abstract topic. Successful presentations will include the use of effective hooks, clear introductions of conflict being resolved, providing clear meaning, and adhering to time constraints.

skills.name: Adapt And Adopt Appropriate Communication Style To Audience

5d8b625e-2dae-4ee5-a003-c6ce9a0bd5ec.description: The critical thinking badge requires the capacity to reason logically and rigorously. Effective critical thinkers have the ability to gather and assess relevant information, identify patterns, question assumptions, and draw well-reasoned conclusions.
5d8b625e-2dae-4ee5-a003-c6ce9a0bd5ec.name: Critical Thinking

badge_template_activities.title: Finding Your Pattern: Through this application exercise, earners will use pattern identification abilities to recognize patterns in themselves using a mind map that addresses a scenario that addresses their goals, values, aptitudes, personal style, and interests. Earners analyze the data collected, reflect on the patterns they discovered, and address common themes identified.

Fact vs. Vapor: Earners demonstrate their capacity to gather and assess relevant information through the use of problem-solving and analysis of facts. Participants are presented with a challenging scenario where they will analyze the situation, assess the facts, and provide a written recommendation Earners will identify core issues, provide thoughtful analysis, distinguish facts from opinions, recognize the role of purpose and bias, and make recommendations supported by evidence.

Thinking Outside the Box: Earners will identify a media source they frequent often. They are tasked with the challenge of identifying hidden assumptions embedded in statements, using the information combined to determine validity. Earners must explain the approach they used to determine if the assumptions are indeed true.

Drawing Conclusions: Earners are presented with a scenario and using the information provided, must draw a conclusion as to final action. Earners demonstrate the willingness to scrutinize evidence, use logic and reasoning to evaluate data, and draw conclusions based on multiple sources of information.

ab661a75-d3c8-41d2-91f0-a0648e32447f.description: Empathy requires the capacity to understand others' perspectives and feelings and to use this understanding to improve the quality of personal and professional relationships, behaviors, team cohesion, and performance. Earners of this badge listen actively, both to what is said explicitly and communicated nonverbally, recognize what others need and value and to validate the feelings and perceptions of colleagues, and incorporate diverse perspectives.
ab661a75-d3c8-41d2-91f0-a0648e32447f.name: Empathy

badge_template_activities.title: Listen Actively: This assessment requires earners to demonstrate active listening skills, including "listening" to what is communicated both verbally and nonverbally. Earners will participate in an interview that requires paraphrasing, asking questions, expressing empathy, using engaged body language, avoiding judgment, and avoiding giving advice.

The Do's & Don'ts of Respectful Listening: Earners will complete an application exercise that requires them to engage in conversation and identify active listening and signals of respect. Earners will identity verbal signals given by the speaker as well as signals presented by the listener. Body language and nonverbal cues are also identified, as well as reflection of how being sensitive to signals helps to improve listening.

Empathy Map: Earners demonstrate their ability to recognize others' values and needs. They must identify an individual they have frequent conflict with and create an empathy map that helps understand that person's point of view. Through this assessment, earns derive insights, demonstrate respect, articulate understanding, and provide sensory details.

Values Across the Aisle: This assessment requires earners to validate others' needs and values by putting themselves in someone else's shoes. Earners must identify an individual that has a conflicting viewpoint on a given topic and engage in a meaningful conversation with them. Crucial to this exercise is avoiding confirmation bias, framing questions, demonstrating respect, and mutual understanding.

50583484-6089-4b51-a8b6-b5681fb579a2.description: Initiative in the 21st century includes self-efficacy and the capacity to identify needs and respond proactively. Earners of this badge demonstrate self-awareness and view both "failures" and "successes" as opportunities to learn and develop. Earners lead without an official "leader" role or title and motivate others and catalyze necessary action when needed.
50583484-6089-4b51-a8b6-b5681fb579a2.name: Initiative

badge_template_activities.title: Sway Your Colleagues: This assessment requires earners to lead without a title. Earners will be presented with a task that requires them to take action and develop a plan to persuade colleagues. Included in the plan must be a collaboration piece with a senior member of the company, as well as clear articulation of the issue. Earners will prepare a clear plan with convincing rationale, persuasive explanation of the issue and need for action, and demonstration of the ability to collaborate.

Petition: Earners will examine the different types of petitions on Change.org. Earners will write a concise petition that tells a compelling story, including the use of graphics or videos, and develop a digital media plan to help publicize the issue and gain signatures.

Demonstrate Self-Awareness: Earners will conduct a self-assessment to demonstrate self-awareness. Through this exercise will demonstrate a sense of self, perspective on how others view them, reflect and recognize different perspectives, reflect on past actions without judgment, describe strategies they use to manage emotions while under stress, and use their awareness of past actions to inform future change.

GRIT Perseverance Walk: After conducting a self-analysis using the GRIT scale, earners will conduct a professional interview with someone they identify as having grit. They will identify someone who has set a difficult goal and was able to achieve it. Earners will develop a written composition clearly articulating the goal of the person, obstacles or struggles they overcame and how they managed them, as well as analyze what their life is like now that they have achieved this goal.

182dc610-04aa-4654-9493-c0a56da76ab9.description: Problem solving in the workplace requires the capacity to solve problems in new ways. Earners that participate in this badge series demonstrate competency in both divergent and convergent thinking, identifying patterns that may not be obvious, managing ambiguity, and applying an iterative process for generating, testing and refining ideas.
182dc610-04aa-4654-9493-c0a56da76ab9.name: Problem Solving

badge_template_activities.title: Tying Up Loose Ends: Earners are presented with a scenario that requires both divergent and convergent thinking. Through critical thinking and problem-solving processes, earner must brainstorm and identify ten innovative solutions, apply an evaluative process, rank solutions based on criteria and usefulness, and finalize their ideas by reflecting on results and processes.

The Crisis: This assessment provides earners with the opportunity to manage ambiguity when presented with a professional challenge. Earners must develop a successful action plan that includes a clear outline with an informed solution based on relevant information, assesses potential consequences, and presents an alternative solution as a parallel plan.

Sparring: This application exercise provides a structured way to gain insights and feedback from teammates and stakeholders. Earners must identify a topic they are looking for peer feedback on. Presenting to a team, earners "spar" by conducting a walk-through of the topic, gain feedback, discuss questions and challenges presented, and develop an iteration of their work based on feedback given.

Finding Your Pattern: Through this application exercise, earners will use pattern identification abilities to recognize patterns in themselves using a mind map that addresses a scenario that addresses their goals, values, aptitudes, personal style, and interests. Earners analyze the data collected, reflect on the patterns they discovered, and address common themes identified.

8fb4065f-6192-45d1-b69f-9ff7d3376f66.description: Resilience includes the capacity to bounce back in the face of stress, challenge, and adversity, not dwelling on disappointment but rather learning from experience and focusing on solutions. Participants that earn this badge exhibit self-awareness, as well as cognitive and emotional flexibility to adjust and adapt.
8fb4065f-6192-45d1-b69f-9ff7d3376f66.name: Resilience

badge_template_activities.title: Demonstrate Self-Awareness: Earners will conduct a self-assessment to demonstrate self-awareness. Through this exercise will demonstrate a sense of self, perspective on how others view them, reflect and recognize different perspectives, reflect on past actions without judgment, describe strategies they use to manage emotions while under stress, and use their awareness of past actions to inform future change.

Growth Chart: This assessment focuses on learning from experience. Earners are charged with the task of creating a growth chart that focuses on three past occasions that did not go as planned (i.e. mistakes or failures). Successful competency requires earners to take responsibility for the role of each failure or mistake, analyze contributing factors, and reframe each incident from a growth perspective.

Preferred Futures: This assessment requires earners to envision life without a current professional problem. Earners identify goals, explore in detail the way they would feel and behave without the problem, define success, and spend minimal time probing the problem.

Exhibit Flexibility: Earners are presented with five different scenarios where they must stay flexible, especially under pressure and in the midst of disappointment and adversity. Earners must choose and explain reasonable options to each scenario, leaving room for opportunities of growth, using rationale based on the reality of situations, and exhibiting an evolving understanding of the situation.
